Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Control of Integrated Wind Turbine and Rechargeable Battery Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to establish a long-term research and educational program in renewable energy, with an initial research focus on the control of an integrated wind turbine and rechargeable battery system to mitigate the effect of wind power intermittency and to maximize the life of rechargeable batteries. The integrated wind turbine and rechargeable battery system provides key enabling technology for broad installation of wind turbines nationwide. The integrated system is a switched system and presents significant challenges for control design. This research aims at understanding the complex system dynamics between the different operating modes and establishing a novel control paradigm to ensure the optimal system performance. The approach includes explicitly deriving a lower bound of the dwell time for a class of switched systems, formulating an innovative optimal nonlinear trajectory control methodology, and developing a physics-based, control-oriented battery state-of-charge model for observer design. Control algorithms will be developed and tested on an industrial-size integrated wind turbine and battery system.

This research will potentially pave the road for wind energy to transform into a major contributor to the nation's overall power supply, help create clean energy jobs, and benefit society at large. The technology developed in this research could be adapted to inland, offshore, and deep-sea floating wind turbine applications. It can be used for megawatts wind farm installations, as well as roof-top single home units. The educational component of the proposal seeks to broaden the participation of members from underrepresented groups in engineering. It also focuses on engaging middle school and high school students, and their teachers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has extended switching control theories to wind turbine systems and established an in-depth understanding of the dynamics when a wind turbine changes between partial load and full load operations. Formulating the wind turbine operation mode change into a switched system has set the foundation for systematically developing new controllers for wind turbine operations. The result of establishing the switching stability using L2 gain for the wind turbine application adds knowledge to the field of wind turbine control. The definition of rise time during switching operation advanced the switching control theorem. The finding could be generalized and applied to a class of switching systems that consist of nonlinear dynamics and linear controllers. For this type of system, once the stability is established, the defined rise time will provide an important indicator of the system performance during switching dynamics.

An optimal control platform was also established as a result of this research effort. Dynamic programming, direct shooting approach, and optimal control with constrained searching spaces have been developed and applied to control of wind turbine systems to achieve optimal tradeoffs among wind energy capture, noise generation, turbine fatigue loading, and impact to the grid stability. The developed optimal control platform proved the feasibility of incorporating component design with control development to achieve an optimal overall system objective. The developed methodology can be adapted to a broad range of industrial applications.

On the front of real-time control, the developed internal torque control and a gain-scheduled pitch control enable the wind turbine to robustly online tract the desired tip speed ratio without knowing the actual turbine power coefficient curve, which is highly difficult if not impossible to obtain, however required by many conventional wind turbine controllers. Even though there exist control methods that do not rely on an accurate knowledge of turbine power coefficient curve, they are normally computational expensive and cannot be applied for real-time control. The developed method, on the other hand, can be readily implemented for real-time control. It adds knowledge to real-time control of wind turbine systems. The developed method can also be applied to other fields, such as manufacturing process control and the financial industry.

Modeling and control of electrochemical devices have been performed during this research as well. Effort on battery modeling has showed that a hybrid neural net and physics-based modeling approach could provide more accurate estimation than either the neural net or the physics-based method alone. This philosophy has also been used to develop a system identification algorithm that incorporates extended Kalman filter (EKF) with physics based model to estimate material properties of batteries. The effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed method was experimentally verified, and its feasibility in real-time control application was also validated.

This research has resulted in 18 journal publications, 15 peer-reviewed conference proceedings, and five PhD dissertations. More than ten graduate students have been trained while working on this project. They have gained expertise on advancing control theorem and technology development. They are inspired by the challenges arising from this project and are enthusiastic for further science and technology explorations. The PI has helped organize a K-12 STEM summer camp for four years as a part of the outreach effort. The campers were exposed to topics including wind turbine operation, solar energy generation and PEM fuel cell vehicles. The integration of lecture, demonstration and hands-on experience has provided an effective way to allow young students to gain knowledge about renewable energy sources and their associated technologies.
